fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-24865].
  {panel}

+Use Case+
# fairly new but brave and wily user named Ima Newby logs into Jira and sees as her default dashboard the system default dashboard. Ima decides she needs something more suited to her needs for her default Jira dashboard and realizes that there is a way to do it
# Ima goes to Tools -> Create Dashboard and chooses to start by creating a blank dashboard

+Expected Result+
Her old Dashboard (the System Dashboard) would still be an option to easily revert back to or look at with 1 click

+Actual Result+
# To find that old Dashboard, Ima Newby has to go to Dashboards -> Manage Dashboards
# click Search
# click the Search button again
# Know that the old Dashboard was called *System Dashboard* (which is highly unlikely that any user other than 1 or 2 administrators know this)
# Scroll through the pages of available dashboards until she finds *System Dashboard* which on our system is on the 19th page of Dashboards

+Solution+
By default all users have the *System Dashboard* as a favorite. Until they make a second dashboard, this solution affects nothing. Once they make a second dashboard, it's much easier for them to un-favorite the System Dashboard than to search for it and re-favorite it.
fields.summary: System Dashboard should by default remain as a favourite after a new user creates a new dashboard

fields.description:
APPLICATION INFO

Jira 4.3.4 Standalone
JDK 1.6.0_24

DESCRIPTION

Jira's quick search navigation (when you key in the exact project issue and it brings you to the issue) just brings you to the general search page instead of the actual issue.

For example, you can key in VOC-3 in quick search, it takes you right to that issue.
However, if you key in V4-99 it doesn't (given that both of these project keys and issues exist within the system).

We realized that we did not have the "jira.projectkey.pattern" set correctly to accept alphanumeric characters, so after we changed that, we rebooted tomcat. Aftering rebooting, the quick search navigation feature won't even work on any type of project key. So, in layman's terms, it's really broken now. 

REPRODUCE PROBLEM

1. Before starting a Jira instance, edit the "jira-application.properties" file and change the "jira.projectkey.pattern" from "([A-Z][A-Z]+)" to "([A-Z][A-Z0-9]+)" - which allows alphanumeric project keys to be created.

NOTE: Before moving on, please understand that step one above was performed in an earlier version of Jira, like version Jira 4.2.*. When we upgraded to Jira 4.3, we forgot to edit this attribute to include these alphanumeric characters. After we realized this, we shutdown Jira, changed this attribute to"([A-Z][A-Z0-9]+)" and restarted Jira. This is when Jira's "quick search" functionality quick working for ALL project key types.

2. Start Jira and create a project with an alphanumeric project key. We have "V8" for our project key. Once you have the project created, create a few test issues.

3. Shut down Jira and re-edit the "jira.projectkey.pattern" and revert it back to its original state "([A-Z][A-Z]+)". 

4. Start Jira back up and see if the quick search navigation works by keying in the exact issue key and number you created, and seeing if the quick search will bring you to that exact project issue, or if it will just bring you to the generic Jira search page. If it brings you to the generic Jira search page, you have successfully recreated the problem, if not, then the problem has not been successfully recreated.

5. If your results above were successful in recreating the problem, shut down Jira again.

6. Change the "jira.projectkey.pattern" back to it's edited format "([A-Z][A-Z0-9]+)". 

7. Restart Jira again, and perform the same search you did before, as well as a search on a project whose key is NOT ALPHANUMERIC - not containing any numbers in the project key. If the issue from the non-alphanumeric project will not display directly from keying it in on the quicksearch, you have completely successfully recreated the problem.
fields.summary: Jira Quick Search Navigation Fails with Alphanumeric Project Key Issues

fields.description:
With JIRA 4.3+ we require users to use InnoDB storage engine when integrating  with MySQL

http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA/Connecting+JIRA+to+MySQL#ConnectingJIRAtoMySQL-2.CreateandConfiguretheMySQLDatabase

However, this isn't the default engine for MySQL (MYISAM) also for various reason ppl may not wish to change the default engine to suite our application.

Anyway, this request is completely unnecessary as MySQL allows to define _storage_engine_ as an attribute for a session.

Funny enough other ATL product already use it... Confluence or Bamboo:

http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/MySQL+5.x

Unaware users will see in fatal errors in their log file:
{noformat}
2011-06-01 23:26:55,334 main ERROR      [core.entity.jdbc.DatabaseUtil] SQL Exception while executing the following:
CREATE INDEX idx_goup_attr_dir_name_lval ON cwd_group_attributes (directory_id, attribute_name, lower_attribute_value)
Error was: com.mysql.jdbc.exceptions.jdbc4.MySQLSyntaxErrorException: Specified key was too long; max key length is 1000 bytes
SQL Exception while executing the following:
CREATE UNIQUE INDEX uk_group_attr_name_lval ON cwd_group_attributes (group_id, attribute_name, lower_attribute_value)
{noformat}

Currently our configurer (config.sh/bat) does not allow to set this attribute on the connection.
fields.summary: Create MySQL tables using InnoDB engine by default - session variable

fields.description:
We recently ran into a situation where a quartz worker thread died due to an error being thrown and services were not being run as a result. We should be able to catch the throwable and attempt to log that it happened so remediation action can be taken.

An associated stack trace:
{code}
011-06-16 10:23:34,563 QuartzWorker-0 ERROR ServiceRunner    Backup Service [jira.bc.dataimport.DefaultExportService] Error exporting Active Objects. You must run JRE 1.6_18 or higher. java.runtime.version: 1.6.0_12-b04
java.lang.NoSuchMethodError: javax.xml.stream.XMLOutputFactory.newFactory(Ljava/lang/String;Ljava/lang/ClassLoader;)Ljavax/xml/stream/XMLOutputFactory;
	at com.atlassian.dbexporter.node.stax.StaxUtils.newXmlOutputFactory(StaxUtils.java:189)
	at com.atlassian.dbexporter.node.stax.StaxUtils.newXmlOutputFactory(StaxUtils.java:172)
	at com.atlassian.dbexporter.node.stax.StaxStreamWriter.createXmlStreamWriter(StaxStreamWriter.java:53)
	at com.atlassian.dbexporter.node.stax.StaxStreamWriter.<init>(StaxStreamWriter.java:39)
	at com.atlassian.activeobjects.backup.ActiveObjectsBackup.save(ActiveObjectsBackup.java:105)
	at com.atlassian.jira.bc.dataimport.DefaultExportService.export(DefaultExportService.java:91)
	at com.atlassian.jira.bc.dataimport.DefaultExportService.export(DefaultExportService.java:53)
	at com.atlassian.jira.service.services.export.ExportService.performBackup(ExportService.java:136)
	at com.atlassian.jira.service.services.export.ExportService.run(ExportService.java:121)
	at com.atlassian.jira.service.JiraServiceContainerImpl.run(JiraServiceContainerImpl.java:60)
	at com.atlassian.jira.service.ServiceRunner.execute(ServiceRunner.java:47)
	at org.quartz.core.JobRunShell.run(JobRunShell.java:195)
	at com.atlassian.multitenant.quartz.MultiTenantThreadPool$MultiTenantRunnable.run(MultiTenantThreadPool.java:72)
	at org.quartz.simpl.SimpleThreadPool$WorkerThread.run(SimpleThreadPool.java:520)
Exception in thread "QuartzWorker-0" java.lang.NoSuchMethodError: Error exporting Active Objects. You must run JRE 1.6_18 or higher. java.runtime.version: 1.6.0_12-b04
	at com.atlassian.jira.bc.dataimport.DefaultExportService.export(DefaultExportService.java:99)
	at com.atlassian.jira.bc.dataimport.DefaultExportService.export(DefaultExportService.java:53)
	at com.atlassian.jira.service.services.export.ExportService.performBackup(ExportService.java:136)
	at com.atlassian.jira.service.services.export.ExportService.run(ExportService.java:121)
	at com.atlassian.jira.service.JiraServiceContainerImpl.run(JiraServiceContainerImpl.java:60)
	at com.atlassian.jira.service.ServiceRunner.execute(ServiceRunner.java:47)
	at org.quartz.core.JobRunShell.run(JobRunShell.java:195)
{code}

caused services not to be run.

In short, a scheduled job that throws anything but a RuntimeException can kill a Quartz scheduler worker thread with no means of recovery. Even a single bad job running every few minutes can completely exhaust the pool of workers before long

h3. Verification

[Generate a Thread Dump|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA/Generating+a+Thread+Dump] and check it to see if there are any QuartzWorker threads running.

h3. Workaround

# Manually flush the mail queue. This must be done as the mail queue is not persisted over restarts - there is a feature request for this under JRA-4665.
# Stop JIRA.
# Replace {{JIRA Installation Directory\atlassian-jira\WEB-INF\lib\quartz-1.5.1.jar}} with [^quartz-1.5.1-atlassian-2.jar].
# Start JIRA.

(!) If you have not identified what's throwing the exception, and fixing it (or disabling it), it is likely that the scheduler may crash again. Reviewing the logs to see if any scheduled jobs are throwing anything but a RuntimeException will identify possible causes.
fields.summary: When the quartz worker dies, there's no warning that services are no longer being run
Move jira.table.cols.subtasks out of jira-application.properties and into DB

fields.description:
JIRA has a feature that allows you to put a custom HTML message at the top of every JIRA page. This is good, and I use it to notify users of problems with, or changes to, JIRA that will affect them. It would be great if these banners were then dismissable by the user (click an 'x') so they don't see it again. Then if the banner changes, it will re-appear. 

Such a feature would be a better way of keeping users up to date with potentially fast changing scenarios. For example, if there are 3 problems with JIRA, and one is solved, then the banner can be changed, and the user will get the update. As it is, all I can do is change the text, or change the colour of the banner. If the user has had the banner on every page for a while, they will start to ignore it, and won't notice small changes.
fields.summary: enhance the Announcement Banner feature to make it user dismissable

fields.description:
We just made the JIRA instance we have public and gave anonymous viewers permissions to browse projects, but nothing else.

Unfortunately, when most of our workflows were made, the creators did not make the 25 clicks necessary to limit each transition's permissions to only people in any project role. Oh, I'm sorry, workflow transitions don't have _permissions_, they have _conditions_. I guess that's why no one thought to include them in the Permission Scheme?

Anyhow, adding these "conditions" to each transition of each of our 22 workflows would be a mammoth task, and I shouldn't be setting these permissions there, anyhow. I should be setting them in the Permission Scheme, where I have also specified who can comment on an issue, and log work on an issue.

Another solution would be to infer who is allowed to transition issues. If someone isn't allowed to comment on an issue, why on earth would I want to allow them to resolve it??
fields.summary: jira workflow permissions should be set in permission scheme

fields.description:
Users in many situations do not want to have the prefix "CLONE - " in subtask's summary when they clone a ticket with its subtasks. Currently, the prefix are added to the subtasks' summary several times if a ticket with its subtasks is cloned several times. (Please see the attached screenshot to illustrate this issue)

- Steps to reproduce this problem.
# create a ticket, and let's say its key is [TEST-1]
# create 3 subtasks within [TEST-1] ticket; [TEST-2], [TEST-3], [TEST-4]
# clone [TEST-1] with its subtasks, and let's say this main ticket is called [TEST-5] with its subtasks ([TEST-6], [TEST-7], [TEST-8]).
# clone [TEST-5] with its subtasks, and let's say this main ticket is called [TEST-9] with its subtasks ([TEST-10], [TEST-11], [TEST-12]).
# clone [TEST-9] with its subtasks, and let's say this main ticket is called [TEST-13] with its subtasks ([TEST-14], [TEST-15], [TEST-16]).
# by this time, the summary of the subtasks of [TEST-14], [TEST-15], [TEST-16] will have a summary called "CLONE - CLONE - CLONE - blah..blah..blah.."

BTW, I can't clone the ticket [TEST-1] to have the ticket [TEST-13] because there are changes in the tickets [TEST-5] and [TEST-9].
Also, I can't remove prefix from jira-application.properties file because users still want to see the prefix "CLONE -" for main tickets, not subtasks.

Although Atlassian fixed JRA-15164, they broke other people's purpose(JSP-81226, JRA-23868). Ideally, jira-application.properties should contain two separate properties to add the prefix for cloning issues: one is for main ticket and the other is for subtasks. In this way, both users' requests can be fulfilled. Could you add this feature in near future JIRA version?

Thanks
fields.summary: Add ability to edit the prefix for subtasks when being cloned.

At this time we are creating items in Jira in bulk, we created various script for that purpose.  In that context, where it is not possible to interface with the "original estimate" field using the SOAP API, we really need to be able to update the field in bulk afterwards. 

While I understand the current limitation on the time tracking as explained here
http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA/Modifying+Multiple+('Bulk')+Issues#ModifyingMultiple%28%27Bulk%27%29Issues-bulkedit

fields.description:
When I create an issue with webservices via the RPC-SOAP-Plugin in Jira I'm not able to set the author of a comment.

First I create the issue.
Then I add the comment with a specific author.  However, the author set in the RemoteComment object that I'm creating the Comment from doesn't set the author in the Issue.  The author is always set to who is authenticated for the soap service.

Currently I'm trying to copy issues from an old Jira system to this new Jira 4.2.3 System as part of our upgrade process.  Without this feature enabled it is blocking us from upgrading.
fields.summary: When using the Jira RPC SOAP Plugin for Jira 4.2.3 and trying to add a comment.  The author of the comment can only be set to the user who is authenticated to the SOAP service.

fields.description:
After installing JIRA 4.4 EAP I clicked on the "Create your first project" link. After that I was on a page with what looked like an error message saying "You do not have the permissions to administer any projects, or there are none created.". Which is confusing because I have admin privileges and I should be able to create a new project.

Only after several minutes I discovered the "Create Project" button at the far left side.

Maybe you can add an extra line of text saying "Click here to create a new project".
fields.summary: Dialog after clicking on "Create your first project" link is confusing
JQL javascript parser approves syntax that server fails.

fields.description:
*Steps to reproduce:*

# Enable websudo.
# Go to the admin page for a project.
# Follow the link to select an issue type scheme for that project. It has a URL of this form: {{/secure/admin/SelectIssueTypeSchemeForProject!default.jspa?projectId=10001&returnUrl=/secure/project/ViewProject.jspa?id=10001}}
# Enter authentication info in the websudo form that is shown and submit the form.

*Result:*

The page that's shown is the one given in the returnUrl argument, i.e.: {{/secure/project/ViewProject.jspa?id=10001}}.

*Expected result:*

It should show the page at the given URL, i.e.: {{/secure/admin/SelectIssueTypeSchemeForProject!default.jspa?projectId=10001}}.

Websudo should also propagate the returnUrl argument to the target form so that submitting the form at this page redirects to the returnUrl, i.e.: submitting or cancelling the form at {{/secure/admin/SelectIssueTypeSchemeForProject!default.jspa?projectId=10001}} should redirect to {{/secure/project/ViewProject.jspa?id=10001}}.
fields.summary: Websudo form treats returnUrl argument incorrectly

fields.description:
*Steps to reproduce*
# Create projects 'TST' and 'TEST'
# Create an issue (TST-1) in 'TST' with file and screenshot attachment
# Make sure that there is a folder (TST-1) in the attachment directory 
# Move the issue (TST-1) to project 'TEST'
# The folder (TST-1) still exist in the attachment directory
# Checking the folder (TST-1), the thumbnail inside the thumb folder still exist too.

Deleting an issue (TEST-1), will remove the folder (TEST-1) in the attachment directory.
JIRA should have deleted the folder (TST-1) after moving the issue to another project too.
fields.summary: Moving an issue across project does not delete the old attachment folder

fields.description:
We need to select which customers are affected by a given issue, from a list of over 400 customer names.

We are currently using a "Multi Select" custom field for this, but it is really hard to use, if you're trying to search through 400 entries, and at the same time, avoiding to unselect customers from the list.

We would like to have a "generic multi value picker" custom field to do this, instead of using the "Multi Select" type, The behavior of the existing multi picker field types seems to be the easiest and safest to use for what we need.

Jira has pickers for "Group Picker", "Multi Group Picker", "Multi User Picker", "Project Picker", "Single Version Picker", "User Picker", and "Version Picker", but not a "Generic Multi Value Picker"...

I've looked in forums, plugins, and this projects for similar requests. I did not find any.

Can you add a "Generic Multi Value Picker" custom field type to jira? Or, is there a plugin that implements it?




Thanks
fields.summary: Generic Multi Value Picker custom field

fields.description:
h4. Introduction
JIRA Charting Plugin comes with Average Time in Status chart and gadget which is purposed to illustrate the average time spent on certain status.

What many people expect is that the date/time an issue will fall under is the date/time that the desired status have taken place in. However, the current behavior is that the date/time an issue will fall under is actually the date/time of when the issue was resolved in.

h4. Usage scenarios explaining the problem:
Imagine a user who wants to know the average time which issues have been in Open status. Imagine that the chosen filter returns 2 issues only (for simplicity):
* Issue A which has been Open in May 2011 and *resolved in May 2011, 
* and Issue B which has been Open in May 2011 and *resolved in June* 2011. That will cause the graph to put Issue A Open time under May 2011 and Issue B Open time under June 2011, which is not what many people would expect.

If this is the expected behavior, I would suggest that we update our documentation [here|http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA/Displaying+Search+Results+as+a+Chart] and [here|https://studio.plugins.atlassian.com/wiki/display/JCHART/JIRA+Charting+Plugin] to be more specific in describing this chart to avoid confusions.

Thank you very much.

Ali
Atlassian Support
fields.summary: Average Time in Status chart relies Issue Resolved status time when distributing the issues in the x-axis, rather than using the configured status time

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-24806].
  {panel}

Need ability to both "Share" Comments or an Issue with users who are not assignees, reporters or watchers.  

First, the comment feature should allow us to "cc" a comment within an issue. Would be nice to have an optional field that allows us to enter an email address. This way, both the reporter and "cc'ed" user gets the comment. 

Currently, we have to email a comment, and then copy paste it back into JIRA issue, which then sends out a notification again to the reporter. Not elegant. 

Second, having a "Share" button in JIRA, like the latest/upcoming Confluence version does would be icing on the cake, so we can share full issues with another user.
fields.summary: Share Comment & Issue feature

fields.description:
Could the documentation pages be modified so that Google Search find the current documentation rather than always hitting the EAP doco.  Google is a nice way of hitting the doco but currently it requires a number of jumps to reach the current version.

Google Search apparently does something a-little-too-smart when indexing the Jira (+Confluence, etc) doco to return the most recent version.  The way things are specified this is the EAP pages not the current doco that appears in search.  Would it be possible to do the version naming of EAP doco slightly differently - eg, 0.4.4 EAP - so that the current doco gets displayed.

(!) This is a general problem not just Jira; I couldn't find a suitable category...
fields.summary: Google search finds EAP documentation

fields.description:
See discussion in  https://support.atlassian.com/browse/GHS-2549

It would be nice to be able to use JIRA's bulk operation facility on most (all?) fields used by Greenhopper and JIRA issues.  Greenhopper's drag and drop of cards works but is not great for large numbers of cards.
fields.summary: Enable "bulk" opeations for most (all?) Greenhopper fields

fields.description:
It's possible for crowd directory attributes such as the LDAP filter string to exceed 255 chars. However, we currently restrict the directory attribute column length for compatibility with indexing requirements for MySQL. 

Currently, the suggested workaround is to manually increase the column length for the cwd_directory_attribute table, but a more sustainable solution needs to be reached.
* https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRAKB/Data+Truncation+due+to+Data+too+long+for+column
fields.summary: Crowd Directory Attributes can exceed 255 chars, causing problems for long but valid LDAP filter strings

fields.summary: Jira can not connect to AD
Possibility to mention a Jira user in a comment

fields.description:
The preview of a work log comment includes paragraph tags, but after logging, they are missing when the work log is actually rendered.

To reproduce,
# start logging work on an issue
# include a blank line between lines, e.g.:
{code}
test

paragraph
{code}
# click the preview button
# look at the HTML source of the preview, confirming paragraph tags
# click the log button
# look at the HTML source of the work log (paragraph tags are missing)

Expected result:  the work log contains paragraph tags for text separated by blank lines.

Work around:  use two pairs of double-backslashes to get a blank line in a work log.
fields.summary: wiki rendering in work log excludes paragraph tags

fields.description:
I fail to find in docs why email notifications from JIRA are bounced by GMail.
Indeed, the emails sent from the same JIRA server via command line "mail ourjirauser@gmail.com" arrive to gmail users just fine!

But JIRA's emails are rejected for some unclear reason:

postfix/smtp[16334]: 206C6102CB8: to=<ourjirauser1@gmail.com>, relay=gmail-smtp-in.l.google.com[209.85.143.27]:25, delay=4.1, delays=0.03/2.2/0.35/1.5, dsn=5.7.1, status=bounced (host gmail-smtp-in.l.google.com[209.85.143.27] said: 550-5.7.1 [ /*our IP goes here */ ] The IP you're using to send mail is not authorized to 550-5.7.1 send email directly to our servers. Please use the SMTP relay at your 550-5.7.1 service provider instead. Learn more at 550 5.7.1 http://mail.google.com/support/bin/answer.py?answer=10336 g60si682138wee.36 (in reply to end of DATA command))

If command line application "mail" can sent email successfully then perhaps JIRA also could do it well. Maybe it just a problem of configuration?
fields.summary: Gmail bounces the email notifications - explain in SMTP documentation how to avoid this

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-24787].
  {panel}

With two different domains one user effectively has two different email addresses - user@domain1 and user@domain2. 
Email handlers should be able recognise that it is the same user and add comment / create issue as appropriate user.

Currently if email to JIRA is sent from user@domain2 JIRA ignores the email.

Studio has already provided this partially by overriding one of JIRA's class. Pleaes see [JST-3171|https://studio.atlassian.com/browse/JST-3171]. Currently this can only be modified by a sysadmin.

This fix does not support assigning issue from email if the assignee's email address is using an alias. Please see [JST-5079|https://studio.atlassian.com/browse/JST-5079] to track its progress.

When JIRA implements this improvement, it would be appreciated to keep this backward compatible with Studio.
fields.summary: Support multiple email domains when creating issues/comments from email

fields.description:
If you visit the IssueNavigator in IE7 it causes a mixed content warning since issue types define and inline style with background-image: url('/some/relative/url').  IE7 can't deal with relative URLs in inline background-image styles and incorrectly shows the mixed content warning.

IE7 users should upgrade to a newer browser, or turn the mixed content warning off in settings.
fields.summary: IssueNavigator causes mixed content warning in IE7 under https

fields.description: When you open the projects dropdown in the header closing it will create a mixed content warning in IE7. This seems to be an IE7 bug with links like: {noformat}homosapien (HSP){noformat} The background-image inline style is what causes the problem. This does not happen in IE8.
fields.summary: Projects dropdown causes mixed content warning in IE7

fields.description:
Steps:
1. login to JIRA.
2. Goto Issue navigator and search for issues.
3. Suppose user has good amount of columns configured for issue navigator. The focus is on the right side of the navigator.
4. Through dot dialog try to search for some operation.

Result:
1. The options in dot dialog are not aligned to the dialog it self.
fields.summary: The .dot dialog drop down is not positioned properly if user is lot of columns configured in issue navigator.
If a user has switched "follow referrals" off, then JIRA should not throw an exception if AD suggests if follow referrals.
When JIRA is caching users from LDAP, it should also store the base dn for the user and the refered server where the user can be authenticated.

fields.description:
If you hide "Affects Version/s" in a Field Configuration, it disappears on the View Issue screen, but leaves an ugly gap.

This seems to be a CSS issue.  The {{#issuedetails}} element is (somewhat mysteriously in my opinion) a UL instead of a table, and the fields are placed on either side with floats.  However, the exact configuration in my screenshot causes too many right-side fields to physically appear in the HTML before *Component/s*, so the floating isn't enough to make everything "collapse" properly.

Bummer.
fields.summary: Hiding "Affects Version/s" in Field Configuration causes an ugly gap in the View Issue screen.

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-24779].
  {panel}

After 9 years of development in our Jira 'TRI' Project, we have more than 1200 versions in total, from which 940 archived. With this long list, it becomes very time consuming to Release, Archive, Unarchive or Delete versions, as it has to be done one by one, while it gets slower and slower because of the number of versions.

The essence of the problem with the Jira Version management functionality is the bad performance with about 1200 versions (or more) in the database. I make the assumption this has to do with the fact that all (>1200) versions are retreived, every time one action (release, archive, unarchive, edit, delete) is done. Moreover, on the project overview screen, just the top 15 version are shown as read-only, and a seperate link to view them all.

The solution I propose is simple; just adding an option (Boolaan, checkbox) on the Jira Version Management screen, someting like 'Show archived versions' (default on No).When this option is No (false), the Archived versions are not retreived after every action, and not (default) shown on the Version Management page. I expect this will largely increase the performance of this functionality.

Kind regards,
Hans Brouwer
Triodos Bank NV 
Netherlands
fields.summary: Performance improvement: Don't show Archived versions by default on the Jira Version management screen

fields.description:
*Steps to reproduce*
# Setup a JIRA instance with Postgresql 8.4
# Create an issue.
# Edit issue due date and manually insert 5 digits year. e.g. 06.06.20111
# JIRA will not throw error regarding date invalidate and will be saved.
# Navigate to Project Summary page, the page will be empty.
|

*Finding*
# This only happen in Postgresql.
# If Mysql is used, exception below will be thrown while click the update button:
{noformat}
Exception occurred: com.atlassian.jira.exception.DataAccessException: org.ofbiz.core.entity.GenericEntityException: while updating: [GenericEntity:Issue][summary,test][status,1][votes,0][fixfor,null][assignee,admin][security,null][resolution,null][resolutiondate,null][type,1][timespent,null][id,10001][reporter,admin][project,10000][environment,null][component,null][updated,2011-06-07 12:57:07.0][created,2011-06-02 13:07:32.0][workflowId,10001][description,null][priority,3][timeestimate,null][duedate,20111-06-15 00:00:00.0][timeoriginalestimate,null][key,TST-2] (SQL Exception while executing the following:UPDATE jiraissue SET pkey=?, PROJECT=?, REPORTER=?, ASSIGNEE=?, issuetype=?, SUMMARY=?, DESCRIPTION=?, ENVIRONMENT=?, PRIORITY=?, RESOLUTION=?, issuestatus=?, CREATED=?, UPDATED=?, DUEDATE=?, RESOLUTIONDATE=?, VOTES=?, TIMEORIGINALESTIMATE=?, TIMEESTIMATE=?, TIMESPENT=?, WORKFLOW_ID=?, SECURITY=?, FIXFOR=?, COMPONENT=? WHERE ID=? (Data truncation: Incorrect datetime value: '20111-06-15 00:00:00.0' for column 'DUEDATE' at row 1))
{noformat}

*Suggestion*
JIRA should validate date field and detect date format more gracefully instead of exception.

*Workaround*
* Locate the invalid date and correct them, after that re index JIRA.

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-24776].
  {panel}

Hello all,
I would like to implement a JIRA project for test management purposes, using 2 different issue types, "Test Plan" and "Test Case".

One "Test Plan" can have more than one "Test Case"
One "Test Case" can relate to more than one "Test Plan" (or if you want "Test Case"'s can be shared among "Test Plan"'s
Each "Test Plan" should aggregate time estimates for all the "Test Case"'s associated to it
Things I have already tried:

Create "Test Plan" and "Test Case" issue types; Link "Test Case"'s to the relevant "Test Plan"'s. OUTCOME: Works fine for sharing "Case"'s among "Plan"'s but does not aggregate time estimates
Create "Test Plan" as issue types and "Test Case"'s as sub-task of a plan. OUTCOME: Works fine for calculating overall "Test Plan"'s estimates but does not allow sharing of "Test Case"'s sub tasks among "Test Plans"
Use Structure to organize the hierarchical model. OUTCOME: Works well for calculating overall estimates by aggregating estimates of each child "Test Case" but does not allow sharing of "Test Case"'s among Test Plan (once a "Test Case" is inserted in the structure under a plan, it is not available any more to be added under a second plan)

When I submitted my issue to JIRA support (https://support.atlassian.com/browse/JSP-81631) I was told that this is unattainable at present but that I should request a new feature to make it possible to share a sub-task (in the example above a Test Case) among more than one parent task (in the example above a Test Plan) and still get the parent issue Test Plan estimates to aggregate the estimates of all the sub-tasks associated to it.

Thanks a million in advance,

Marco
fields.summary: Allowing sharing a sub-task among parent tasks

fields.description:
We have identified and fixed a number of cross-site scripting (XSS) vulnerabilities in JIRA issue links and labels.

Affected versions are 4.2.x to 4.3.x

XSS vulnerabilities potentially allow an attacker to embed their own JavaScript into a JIRA page. You can read more about XSS attacks at various places on the web, including these:

* cgisecurity.com: http://www.cgisecurity.com/articles/xss-faq.shtml
* The Web Application Security Consortium: http://projects.webappsec.org/Cross-Site+Scripting

This issue is reported in our security advisory on this page:

* https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA/JIRA+Security+Advisory+2011-09-27
fields.summary: XSS Vulnerability in Issue Links and Labels

fields.description:
For consistency User Session page should use the 24h format. However, appears to report time in an incomplete am/pm format.
 
Currently, it does not display the am/pm indicator for displayed time which can be confusing.

!usersessiontime.png!

Displayed time is actually 23.45 or 11.45pm.

Original bug report provided by Xavier:
{quote}
The times shown in the User Sessions section are offset from System Time. In my case, it appears to be 12 hours.
The system time is correct, using a date command at the prompt returns "Mon Jun  6 23:42:23 UTC 2011".
The system time shown in Administration -> System -> System info is correct. See attached systeminfotime.png
But system time shown in User Sessions is incorrect. See attached userinfotime.png

I don't remember seeing this before, and not sure if it's a problem related to a recent system upgrade (Postgre SQL updated amongst other things). So happy to accept it being a result of some other change. I have restarted JIRA to no avail, but system hasn't been rebooted.

Note that I've blanked sections to retain privacy.
{quote}
fields.summary: Incorrect time format in User Sessions page.

fields.description:
Create a filter that only shows open/in progress/reopened bugs. Now use that filter in a Created vs. Resolved gadget. You'll get a permanently red graph in which issues are only created, never resolved.

This behavior is understandable since the gadget is applying the filter first so it will never see any resolved issues... but it makes the gadget less useful, since it means for a typical use case in which you have a dashboard for some particular project/label/etc., you'll usually need to create at least two filters, one for your open issues and one just for this gadget.

If the gadget has access to the details of the filter, it'd be nice if it could make a temporary change to it (i.e. if it sees that resolved issues are excluded, do a query with resolved issues included) or, failing that, at least display a note indicating that this created/resolved graph is not really valid.
fields.summary: Created vs. Resolved gadget doesn't work with a filter of open bugs

fields.description:
How it works right now:

# Create a "Draft" workflow which is separate from the "Active" workflow
# Edit it
# Save it and overwrite the active workflow; now your changes take effect.

How it could work instead:

# Edit the "Active" workflow.  Under the hood, JIRA silently creates a "Draft" workflow which is affected by your changes.
# Save it; now your changes take effect.

This is not very different from a technical perspective, but is conceptually simpler for the administrator.  Instead of creating and destroying a draft workflow, you can hit "Save" or "Discard Changes", just like editing documents on other platforms.
fields.summary: Simpler UX for editing active workflows

fields.description: I really like the fact that JIRA now has an IssueService to handle the create and update of issues.  It still seems to be lacking in certain areas however, one of which is the default assignee resolution.  If you create an issue using the IssueService, all configurations regarding the default assignee are ignored.  It appears that JIRA is relying on the logic in the AssigneeSystemField to handle population of the correct default values, which is fine if the values are coming from the web UI -- but makes no sense when directly interacting with the IssueService.  This is the type of logic that should be encapsulated in the IssueService so you don't have to worry about manually applying extra business rules during issue creation.
fields.summary: Creating issues via the IssueService does not apply default assignee logic

fields.description:
We have Jira set up with a large number of projects with a small number of issues. Because of this, we have a lot of information in the project description that we frequently need to access. It doesn't appear that the quick search includes general product information in its searches, which greatly slows down the process of finding what we need. Essentially the only workaround I've found is to display the full project list and use the browser's search to find the name I want.

For example, if we have a contact name and phone number in the project description and we search for the contact name, no results are found. It appears it partially searches the project key - if I have a project with a key of MYNAME that has at least one issue, a search for "MYNAME" will turn up the issues, while a search for "NAME" won't.

I would like the quick search to include the general project information.

Thank you.
fields.summary: Search Project Information
